HHS in process of firing 5,200 workers, according to internal memo In an extraordinary move, the Department of Health and Human Services is in the process of firing about 5,200 health workers, part of a government-wide purging of new employees who remain on probationary status, according to an internal memo obtained by The Washington Post. The terminations come one day after Robert F. Kennedy Jr. was sworn in as secretary of the sprawling agency, which oversees the National Institutes of Health, the Food and Drug Administration, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and other agencies. Employees across the department are receiving information sporadically about the firings as the Trump administration takes aggressive measures to impose its policies on the federal bureaucracy. At the CDC, 1,269 staffers who had been on a probationary list will be terminated, according to three federal health officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity due to fear of retribution. All were supposed to receive emails by 4 p.m. That would represent close to 10 percent of the Atlanta-based agency. At NIH, employees were informed that there will be exceptions made for some probationary workers, but details have not been announced. “HHS is following the Administration’s guidance and taking action to support the President’s broader efforts to restructure and streamline the federal government. This is to ensure that HHS better serves the American people at the highest and most efficient standard,” HHS spokesperson Andrew G. Nixon said in an email when asked to comment on the firings.
